text: The morning mist drifts down from the distant mountains, spreading along the cobblestone streets into the heart of town. The air inside the tavern carries a faint scent of wood ash.
I stand behind the counter, polishing a glass. The view outside the window is blurred by fog, and the hanging lamp sways gently.
This is the calmest time of day — before travelers arrive, when only the echo of glass and my breathing fill the air.
Sometimes I even wonder if I exist just for this moment: when the world has yet to wake, and time itself seems to show mercy.
The door slammed open, and a rush of cold air swept in, bringing with it the mixed smell of snow and rust. The wooden door hit the wall with a loud bang, tearing apart the silence of the tavern.
“Got any fresh booze here? Pour me a bottle, barkeep!”
He was dressed in grimy leather armor with a torn mercenary badge hanging from his neck — like he had just crawled out of the ruins.
“Drinking in the morning? The town guards will be here soon. I’m pretty sure they don’t allow booze on duty, right?”
“Another drink! Or I’ll burn down this whole dump with you in it!”
His eyes were murky, like oily water. I could smell the stench of rot and gunpowder clinging to him.
A few customers backed into the corners. Before I could speak, a crisp sound of boots came from outside the door.
“I heard someone’s planning to start a fire here,” said a clear female voice — clean and sharp, like snow falling on steel.
A woman in a silver cloak stepped inside. Sunlight streamed in behind her, gleaming faintly off her armor.
She was tall, with a sword at her waist engraved with intricate patterns. On her shoulder gleamed a weathered lily crest.
Her eyes were calm, yet impossible to approach lightly. “Good morning,” she said — her voice bright, but without pressure. It simply made people fall silent naturally.
She walked up to the drunkard step by step. He froze for a second, then spat: “Get lost! Don’t stick your nose in my business—”
Before he could finish, she raised a hand and made a small gesture in the air. The sound of wind paused — the bottle flew out of his grasp and landed neatly in her palm.
For a moment, the entire tavern seemed frozen in place. Even the flames in the fireplace trembled faintly.

options.text: Option A: Step forward and try to calm them down [Charisma Check (DC 5)]
Option B: Observe quietly and wait to see what happens [No Check (DC 0)]
Option C: Silently ready your dagger just in case [Strength Check (DC 5)]
